elements.content: The hydrothermal reaction of cadmium nitrate hydrate (Cd(NO3)2·4H2O) with p-terphenyl-type 4,4′-(1,4-phenylene)bis(2,6-dimethyl-3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid) (H4L), and phenanthroline (phen) in the presence of triethylamine leads to a three-dimensional supramolecular aggregate {[Cd3(phen)3(HL)2(H2O)2]·4.25H2O} n (1). In 1, the T-type second building units construct independent one-dimensional (1-D) metal−organic nanotubes (MONTs) with 63 topology containing distinct axially asymmetric subunits [R-Cd3(HL) and S-Cd3(HL)]. The adjacent RR-Cd5(HL)2 supersubunits form a hydrophilic intertube chiral channel (I), and the SS-Cd5(HL)2 supersubunits generate another type of hydrophilic intertube chiral channel (II). These two types of chiral channels encapsulate two corresponding types of helical water-chains with three pseudo screw axes, exhibiting a novel chirality transformation and transfer, namely, R-Cd3(HL) → RR-Cd5(HL)2 → chiral channel (I) → left-handed (M) water-helix, and S-Cd3(HL) → SS-Cd5(HL)2 → chiral channel (II) → right-handed (P) water-helix. Photoluminescence and nitrogen adsorption behavior of 1 have been examined.
elements.clean_text: The hydrothermal reaction of cadmium nitrate hydrate (Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O) with p-terphenyl-type 4,4'-(1,4-phenylene)bis(2,6-dimethyl-3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid) (H4L), and phenanthroline (phen) in the presence of triethylamine leads to a three-dimensional supramolecular aggregate {[Cd3(phen)3(HL)2(H2O)2]⋅4.25H2O} n  (1). In 1, the T-type second building units construct independent one-dimensional (1-D) metal-organic nanotubes (MONTs) with 63 topology containing distinct axially asymmetric subunits [R-Cd3(HL) and S-Cd3(HL)]. The adjacent RR-Cd5(HL)2 supersubunits form a hydrophilic intertube chiral channel (I), and the SS-Cd5(HL)2 supersubunits generate another type of hydrophilic intertube chiral channel (II). These two types of chiral channels encapsulate two corresponding types of helical water-chains with three pseudo screw axes, exhibiting a novel chirality transformation and transfer, namely, R-Cd3(HL) → RR-Cd5(HL)2 → chiral channel (I) → left-handed (M) water-helix, and S-Cd3(HL) → SS-Cd5(HL)2 → chiral channel (II) → right-handed (P) water-helix. Photoluminescence and nitrogen adsorption behavior of 1 have been examined.

elements.content: A three-dimensional supramolecular aggregate {[Cd3(phen)3(HL)2(H2O)2]·4.25H2O} n (1) contains independent one-dimensional metal−organic nanotubes (MONTs) with 63 topology containing distinct axially asymmetric subunits [R-Cd3(HL) and S-Cd3(HL)]. Two types of intertube chiral channels encapsulate two corresponding types of helical water-chains with three pseudo screw axes, exhibiting a novel chirality transformation and transfer, namely, R-Cd3(HL) → RR-Cd5(HL)2 → chiral channel (I) → left-handed (M) water-helix, and S-Cd3(HL) → SS-Cd5(HL)2 → chiral channel (II) → right-handed (P) water-helix.
elements.clean_text: A three-dimensional supramolecular aggregate {[Cd3(phen)3(HL)2(H2O)2]⋅4.25H2O} n  (1) contains independent one-dimensional metal-organic nanotubes (MONTs) with 63 topology containing distinct axially asymmetric subunits [R-Cd3(HL) and S-Cd3(HL)]. Two types of intertube chiral channels encapsulate two corresponding types of helical water-chains with three pseudo screw axes, exhibiting a novel chirality transformation and transfer, namely, R-Cd3(HL) → RR-Cd5(HL)2 → chiral channel (I) → left-handed (M) water-helix, and S-Cd3(HL) → SS-Cd5(HL)2 → chiral channel (II) → right-handed (P) water-helix.

elements.content: Since the discovery of carbon nanotubes, tubular metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) have received considerable attention due to not only their wide structural diversity but also their properties of host−guest chemistry associated with intertube and intratube cavities, such as storage, delivery, molecular recognition, etc. So far many MOFs with one-dimensional or intersecting channels have been synthesized, but only a few nanotubular MOFs have been documented in the literature, for example, [Ag7(tpst)4(ClO4)2(NO3)5(dmf)2] n , {[Ln(dipic)3Mn1.5(H2O)3]·nH2O}, and [ZnF(AmTAZ)]. And the tubular units contained in the above MOFs were generally further bridged by other moieties to build highly dimensional coordinate frameworks. Therefore, it is an interesting challenge to synthesize independent one-dimensional (1-D) metal−organic nanotubes (MONTs). Dong and co-workers have reported a novel MONT [AgL(BF4)·0.5(C6H6)] (L = a flexible N-ligand). Lately, an attractive MONT with Zn4(bpy)4 (bpy = 4,4′-bipyridyl) squares has been documented by Sun and co-workers.
elements.clean_text: Since the discovery of carbon nanotubes, tubular metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have received considerable attention due to not only their wide structural diversity but also their properties of host-guest chemistry associated with intertube and intratube cavities, such as storage, delivery, molecular recognition, etc. So far many MOFs with one-dimensional or intersecting channels have been synthesized, but only a few nanotubular MOFs have been documented in the literature, for example, [Ag7(tpst)4(ClO4)2(NO3)5(dmf)2] n , {[Ln(dipic)3Mn1.5(H2O)3]⋅nH2O}, and [ZnF(AmTAZ)]. And the tubular units contained in the above MOFs were generally further bridged by other moieties to build highly dimensional coordinate frameworks. Therefore, it is an interesting challenge to synthesize independent one-dimensional (1-D) metal-organic nanotubes (MONTs). Dong and co-workers have reported a novel MONT [AgL(BF4)⋅0.5(C6H6)] (L = a flexible N-ligand). Lately, an attractive MONT with Zn4(bpy)4 (bpy = 4,4'-bipyridyl) squares has been documented by Sun and co-workers.

elements.content: Recently, p-terphenyl-type organic moieties have been increasingly investigated due to their use in the synthesis of atropisomers, molecular motors, conformation-dependent optic materials, and mimetic α-helix. On the other hand, the pyridine-carboxylate ligands, such as 2,3-/2,4-/2,5-/2,6-/3,5-pyridinedicarboxylates (PDCs), have been widely used to built various MOFs and supramolecular networks because of their versatile coordination modes as well as hydrogen-bonding donors or acceptors. In our previous studies, 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylate with a rigid group, for example, methyl, thienyl, or phenyl, has exhibited different properties from that of the common 3,5-PDC in crystal engineering. As a continuation of our work, we designed and synthesized a new p-terphenyl-type tetracarboxylic acid, 4,4′-(1,4-phenylene)bis(2,6-dimethyl-3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid) (H4L) (see ), in which the pyridine groups could act as hydrophilic sites for the supramolecular self-organization of MOFs, and the restriction of rotation around the aryl−aryl bond is expected to lead to interesting axially asymmetry structures. Herein we present a novel 1-D MONT with 63 topology in which distinct asymmetric subunits construct hydrophilic intertube channels encapsulating rare helical water-chains.
elements.clean_text: Recently, p-terphenyl-type organic moieties have been increasingly investigated due to their use in the synthesis of atropisomers, molecular motors, conformation-dependent optic materials, and mimetic α-helix. On the other hand, the pyridine-carboxylate ligands, such as 2,3-/2,4-/2,5-/2,6-/3,5-pyridinedicarboxylates (PDCs), have been widely used to built various MOFs and supramolecular networks because of their versatile coordination modes as well as hydrogen-bonding donors or acceptors. In our previous studies, 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylate with a rigid group, for example, methyl, thienyl, or phenyl, has exhibited different properties from that of the common 3,5-PDC in crystal engineering. As a continuation of our work, we designed and synthesized a new p-terphenyl-type tetracarboxylic acid, 4,4'-(1,4-phenylene)bis(2,6-dimethyl-3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid) (H4L) (see ), in which the pyridine groups could act as hydrophilic sites for the supramolecular self-organization of MOFs, and the restriction of rotation around the aryl-aryl bond is expected to lead to interesting axially asymmetry structures. Herein we present a novel 1-D MONT with 63 topology in which distinct asymmetric subunits construct hydrophilic intertube channels encapsulating rare helical water-chains.

elements.content: The hydrothermal reaction of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O, H4L, phenanthroline (phen) and triethylamine in H2O produces a 3-D nanosized thick tubes aggregate {[Cd3(phen)3(HL)2(H2O)2]·4.25H2O} n (1). Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric R3̅c (No. 167) space group. The asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Cd(II) ions (Cd1 and Cd2), one HL ligand, and 3/2 phen blocks (Figure a). The N−H bond of anionic HL is confirmed by a characteristic peak (ṽ N−H = 3270 cm−1) in the Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrum of 1. The ratio of Cd1 ions to Cd2 ions is 2:1 in 1. The geometry around the Cd1 atom can be described as a distorted octahedron (CdO4N2). All six binding sites of Cd1 are provided by three O atoms (O1A; O5; O6) from two equivalent HL ligands, one water molecule (O9), and two N atoms (N3; N4) of one phen ligand. The Cd1−O bond lengths are in the range 2.251(7)−2.659(2) Å. The Cd1−N bond lengths are 2.337(9) and 2.371(9) Å, respectively. The Cd2 atom also has a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, and the six basal positions are filled with O7; O8; O7A; O8A atoms from two equivalent HL ligands, and two N atoms (N5; N5A) of one phen. The Cd2−N bond length ranges from 2.22(5) to 2.35(4) Å (the phen is disordered), and the Cd2−O bond lengths fall in the range 2.276(8)−2.425(8) Å. All the bond lengths are in agreement with those reported in other Cd(II) complexes of N,O-mixed ligands.

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that compound 1 crystallizes in the centrosymmetric R3̅c (No. 167) space group. The asymmetric unit contains two crystallographically independent Cd(II) ions (Cd1 and Cd2), one HL ligand, and 3/2 phen blocks (Figure a). The N-H bond of anionic HL is confirmed by a characteristic peak (ṽ N-H = 3270 cm-1) in the Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrum of 1. The ratio of Cd1 ions to Cd2 ions is 2:1 in 1. The geometry around the Cd1 atom can be described as a distorted octahedron (CdO4N2). All six binding sites of Cd1 are provided by three O atoms (O1A; O5; O6) from two equivalent HL ligands, one water molecule (O9), and two N atoms (N3; N4) of one phen ligand. The Cd1-O bond lengths are in the range 2.251(7)-2.659(2) Å. The Cd1-N bond lengths are 2.337(9) and 2.371(9) Å, respectively. The Cd2 atom also has a distorted octahedral coordination geometry, and the six basal positions are filled with O7; O8; O7A; O8A atoms from two equivalent HL ligands, and two N atoms (N5; N5A) of one phen. The Cd2-N bond length ranges from 2.22(5) to 2.35(4) Å (the phen is disordered), and the Cd2-O bond lengths fall in the range 2.276(8)-2.425(8) Å. All the bond lengths are in agreement with those reported in other Cd(II) complexes of N,O-mixed ligands.

elements.content: Crystal structure of 1. (a) Coordination environments of Cd(II) ions and HL ligands, and the simplified T-type second building unit (SBU). (b) The 1-D metal−organic nanotube (MONT) with 12-membered rings from SBUs by sharing the Cd(II) atoms. The yellow cylinder is artificial. Lavender ball HL, and azure Cd. Other groups are omitted for clarity. (c) The abstracted 1-D 63 topological framework (left), and its top view (right). (d) The near coplanar turbine-like (HL)6 hexamer (denoted as the orange hexagon). The green break-lines represent N1−H1···O3/O4 H-bonds. (e) Top view of the alternative assembly of A and B layers along the c axis direction. A = [Cd2(phen)]3, B = [(HL)Cd1(phen)]6. (f) Side view of the A-B-A′-B′ arrangement in the MONT (A = A′, B = B′, d1 = 3.434 Å, d2 = 6.979 Å).
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structure of 1. (a) Coordination environments of Cd(II) ions and HL ligands, and the simplified T-type second building unit (SBU). (b) The 1-D metal-organic nanotube (MONT) with 12-membered rings from SBUs by sharing the Cd(II) atoms. The yellow cylinder is artificial. Lavender ball HL, and azure Cd. Other groups are omitted for clarity. (c) The abstracted 1-D 63 topological framework (left), and its top view (right). (d) The near coplanar turbine-like (HL)6 hexamer (denoted as the orange hexagon). The green break-lines represent N1-H1⋅⋅⋅O3/O4 H-bonds. (e) Top view of the alternative assembly of A and B layers along the c axis direction. A = [Cd2(phen)]3, B = [(HL)Cd1(phen)]6. (f) Side view of the A-B-A'-B' arrangement in the MONT (A = A', B = B', d1 = 3.434 Å, d2 = 6.979 Å).

elements.content: The HL serves as an exo-tridenate ligand and bridges three Cd atoms through the O1, O5, O6, O7, and O8 atoms. The Cd···Cd separations over the HL bridge are in the range 8.989−10.047 Å. The Cd3(HL) can be simplified as a T-type second building unit (SBU) with the HL as a three-connected (3-c) node (Figure a). Through sharing the Cd atoms, the SBUs construct a fascinating independent 1-D metal−organic nanotube (MONT) composed of [Cd3(HL)2] n (Figure b). The inner diameter of the 12-membered neutral MONT without phenthnoline (phen) blocks is ca. 20 Å (nuclear-to-nuclear Cd···Cd separation). If the HL ligand is treated as the only node, the MONT can be further simplified as a uninodal 3-c framework with Schläfli symbol of 63 (Figure c), which is related to the structural prototype of single-wall carbon nanotube (SWCN). The MONT also looks like a cylinder produced from a two-dimensional (6, 3) sheet-like layer through either roll or seal at opposing edges. It should be noted, the MONT in 1 presents the first independent 1-D metal−organic nanotube with the SWCN topology according to our knowledge.
elements.clean_text: The HL serves as an exo-tridenate ligand and bridges three Cd atoms through the O1, O5, O6, O7, and O8 atoms. The Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd separations over the HL bridge are in the range 8.989-10.047 Å. The Cd3(HL) can be simplified as a T-type second building unit (SBU) with the HL as a three-connected (3-c) node (Figure a). Through sharing the Cd atoms, the SBUs construct a fascinating independent 1-D metal-organic nanotube (MONT) composed of [Cd3(HL)2] n  (Figure b). The inner diameter of the 12-membered neutral MONT without phenthnoline (phen) blocks is ca. 20 Å (nuclear-to-nuclear Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd separation). If the HL ligand is treated as the only node, the MONT can be further simplified as a uninodal 3-c framework with Schläfli symbol of 63 (Figure c), which is related to the structural prototype of single-wall carbon nanotube (SWCN). The MONT also looks like a cylinder produced from a two-dimensional (6, 3) sheet-like layer through either roll or seal at opposing edges. It should be noted, the MONT in 1 presents the first independent 1-D metal-organic nanotube with the SWCN topology according to our knowledge.

elements.content: Another noticeable structural feature of the MONT is the layer-up-layer arrangement of HL ligands and phenthnoline (phen) blocks along the c-axis direction (Figure e). HL ligands form interesting clockwise and anticlockwise nanosized turbine-like (HL)6 hexamers containing hydrogen-bonded R6 6(36) nanorings (N1···O4 2.648 Å) (Figure d). In the hexamer, six pyridine (N1) rings are nearly coplanar. Two types of turbine-like hexamers are alternately situated in the MONT along the c-axis direction (). On the other hand, all phen(N5) ligands coordinated with Cd2 atoms are situated inside the MONT, while phen (N3,N4) groups chelating Cd1 centers locate at the outside. A coplanar A layer exists composed of [Cd2(phen)]3, and a near coplanar B consists of (HL)6 and [Cd1(phen)]6 (Figure e). The A and the B layers alternatively array in an A-B-A′-B′ fashion along the c-axis direction. The rotation angle of A and A′ is 60°, while that of B and B′ is ca. 25°. The resulting MONT has the thickness of 15 Å (8 Å inner diameter, 38 Å outer diameter, nuclear-to-nuclear H···H separation, ). Moreover, two disorder crystallographically independent solvent water molecules (O12 and O15) occupy the tubular cavity of the MONT.
elements.clean_text: Another noticeable structural feature of the MONT is the layer-up-layer arrangement of HL ligands and phenthnoline (phen) blocks along the c-axis direction (Figure e). HL ligands form interesting clockwise and anticlockwise nanosized turbine-like (HL)6 hexamers containing hydrogen-bonded R6 6(36) nanorings (N1⋅⋅⋅O4 2.648 Å) (Figure d). In the hexamer, six pyridine (N1) rings are nearly coplanar. Two types of turbine-like hexamers are alternately situated in the MONT along the c-axis direction (). On the other hand, all phen(N5) ligands coordinated with Cd2 atoms are situated inside the MONT, while phen (N3,N4) groups chelating Cd1 centers locate at the outside. A coplanar A layer exists composed of [Cd2(phen)]3, and a near coplanar B consists of (HL)6 and [Cd1(phen)]6 (Figure e). The A and the B layers alternatively array in an A-B-A'-B' fashion along the c-axis direction. The rotation angle of A and A' is 60°, while that of B and B' is ca. 25°. The resulting MONT has the thickness of 15 Å (8 Å inner diameter, 38 Å outer diameter, nuclear-to-nuclear H⋅⋅⋅H separation, ). Moreover, two disorder crystallographically independent solvent water molecules (O12 and O15) occupy the tubular cavity of the MONT.

elements.content: The 1-D MONTs further produce an interesting 3-D supramolecular aggregate (Figure ). In 1, each MONT is interacted with six equivalent MONTs through the intertube face-to-face π−π interactions of 3.5 Å between phen (N3, N4) blocks (). Because of the existence of obstructive phen entities, the 3-D supramolecular architecture only has a void of 5.4% (2020.6 Å3 out of the unit cell of 37656.0 Å3) as calculated by PLATON.
elements.clean_text: The 1-D MONTs further produce an interesting 3-D supramolecular aggregate (Figure ). In 1, each MONT is interacted with six equivalent MONTs through the intertube face-to-face π-π interactions of 3.5 Å between phen (N3, N4) blocks (). Because of the existence of obstructive phen entities, the 3-D supramolecular architecture only has a void of 5.4% (2020.6 Å3 out of the unit cell of 37656.0 Å3) as calculated by PLATON.

elements.content: The 3-D supramolecular architecture of metal−organic nanotubes (MONTs) from SBUs and phen ligands. The intertube channels alternately envelop left-handed (M) and right-handed (P) helical water-chains. Methyl groups, other H2O molecules, and H atoms are omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  The 3-D supramolecular architecture of metal-organic nanotubes (MONTs) from SBUs and phen ligands. The intertube channels alternately envelop left-handed (M) and right-handed (P) helical water-chains. Methyl groups, other H2O molecules, and H atoms are omitted for clarity.

elements.content: Interestingly, in the supramolecular 1 hydrophilic intertube channels exist encapsulating two types of rare helical water-chains (Figure ). In order to make clear the relationship between the intertube channel and the water-helix, it is necessary to investigate the conformation of HL ligands in the MONT. In the crystal structure of HL ligand, the rotation of pyridyl ring around the aryl−aryl bond is greatly hindered for coordination of carboxylate groups to Cd(II) ions, and the dihedral angle of two pyridyl groups is ca. 80°. Two carboxylates (denoted as C23 and C22) on the pyridyl (N2) are located in different chemical microenvironments (Figure a). And the chemical environment of C13 carboxylate is also different from that of C14 carboxylate on the pyridyl (N1) ring. According to the Cahn-Ingold-Prelog sequence rule, the Cd2 atom has priority to the Cd1 because the Cd1 is coordinated with H2O (O9), namely, Cd2 > Cd1 (Figure a). Then, the C23 is prior to the C22 (C23 > C22). Similarly, the C13 is prior to the C14 since the C14 carboxylate is free. Consequently, two distinct asymmetric subunits exist in the same MONT, that is, R-Cd3(HL) and S-Cd3(HL) (Figure ). Remarkably, each Cd1 center links one R-Cd3(HL) and one S-Cd3(HL) (Figure ), while each Cd2 atom connects either two R-Cd3(HL) or two S-Cd3(HL) subunits (Figure a). This unique linkage produces two kinds of asymmetric supersubunits, namely, RR-Cd5(HL)2 and SS-Cd5(HL)2. In particular, the supersubunits alternately array and incline with an angle of ca. 30° along the c axis of MONT, and the hydrophilic pyridine rings (N2) are situated on the surface of the MONT ().
elements.clean_text: Interestingly, in the supramolecular 1 hydrophilic intertube channels exist encapsulating two types of rare helical water-chains (Figure ). In order to make clear the relationship between the intertube channel and the water-helix, it is necessary to investigate the conformation of HL ligands in the MONT. In the crystal structure of HL ligand, the rotation of pyridyl ring around the aryl-aryl bond is greatly hindered for coordination of carboxylate groups to Cd(II) ions, and the dihedral angle of two pyridyl groups is ca. 80°. Two carboxylates (denoted as C23 and C22) on the pyridyl (N2) are located in different chemical microenvironments (Figure a). And the chemical environment of C13 carboxylate is also different from that of C14 carboxylate on the pyridyl (N1) ring. According to the Cahn-Ingold-Prelog sequence rule, the Cd2 atom has priority to the Cd1 because the Cd1 is coordinated with H2O (O9), namely, Cd2 > Cd1 (Figure a). Then, the C23 is prior to the C22 (C23 > C22). Similarly, the C13 is prior to the C14 since the C14 carboxylate is free. Consequently, two distinct asymmetric subunits exist in the same MONT, that is, R-Cd3(HL) and S-Cd3(HL) (Figure ). Remarkably, each Cd1 center links one R-Cd3(HL) and one S-Cd3(HL) (Figure ), while each Cd2 atom connects either two R-Cd3(HL) or two S-Cd3(HL) subunits (Figure a). This unique linkage produces two kinds of asymmetric supersubunits, namely, RR-Cd5(HL)2 and SS-Cd5(HL)2. In particular, the supersubunits alternately array and incline with an angle of ca. 30° along the c axis of MONT, and the hydrophilic pyridine rings (N2) are situated on the surface of the MONT ().

elements.content: (a) Sectional crystal structure in the metal−organic nanotube. (b) A view of absolute configurations of S- and R-Cd3(HL) subunits. S : C23 → C22 → C13; R : C23A → C22A → C13A.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Sectional crystal structure in the metal-organic nanotube. (b) A view of absolute configurations of S- and R-Cd3(HL) subunits.  S : C23 → C22 → C13;  R : C23A → C22A → C13A.

elements.content: (a) The crystal structures of RR-Cd5(HL)2 and SS-Cd5(HL)2 super-subunits, and their simplified motifs. (b) The spontaneously assembly of RR-Cd5(HL)2 and SS-Cd5(HL)2 super-subunits from equivalent MONTs contains two distinct hydrophilic intertube channels trapping two types of helical water-chains. (c) Top view of intertube channels containing water-helices encircled by V-type chiral building blocks, and the extended 5-fold helices.
elements.clean_text: 4  (a) The crystal structures of RR-Cd5(HL)2 and SS-Cd5(HL)2 super-subunits, and their simplified motifs. (b) The spontaneously assembly of RR-Cd5(HL)2 and SS-Cd5(HL)2 super-subunits from equivalent MONTs contains two distinct hydrophilic intertube channels trapping two types of helical water-chains. (c) Top view of intertube channels containing water-helices encircled by V-type chiral building blocks, and the extended 5-fold helices.

elements.content: As has been documented in the work by Mukherjee and Xu et al., a chiral microenvironment can be induced by chiral components. In the 3-D supramolecular network of 1, with the pyridine rings (N2) as functional groups, the RR-Cd5(HL)2 supersubunits from three equivalent MONTs assemble a hydrophilic intertube chiral channel (I); the SS-Cd5(HL)2 super-subunits generate another hydrophilic intertube chiral channel (II) (Figure b). As illustrated in Figure c, the distance between two neighboring Cd1 atoms (Cd1 and Cd1′) in two RR-Cd5(HL)2 or SS-Cd5(HL)2 supersubunits is about 8.45 Å (). If the RR-Cd5(HL)2 and the SS-Cd5(HL)2 are simplified as V-type chiral building blocks (Figure a), two kinds of extended 5-fold helices are produced through Cd1-to-Cd1′ stretch (8.45 Å) (Figure c, ). Then the chiral channels (I) encircled by RR-Cd5(HL)2 supersubunits is equivalent to the left-handed (M) helical channel, while the chiral channels (II) encircled by SS-Cd5(HL)2 supersubunits is equivalent to the right-handed (P) helical channel.
elements.clean_text: As has been documented in the work by Mukherjee and Xu et al., a chiral microenvironment can be induced by chiral components. In the 3-D supramolecular network of 1, with the pyridine rings (N2) as functional groups, the RR-Cd5(HL)2 supersubunits from three equivalent MONTs assemble a hydrophilic intertube chiral channel (I); the SS-Cd5(HL)2 super-subunits generate another hydrophilic intertube chiral channel (II) (Figure b). As illustrated in Figure c, the distance between two neighboring Cd1 atoms (Cd1 and Cd1') in two RR-Cd5(HL)2 or SS-Cd5(HL)2 supersubunits is about 8.45 Å (). If the RR-Cd5(HL)2 and the SS-Cd5(HL)2 are simplified as V-type chiral building blocks (Figure a), two kinds of extended 5-fold helices are produced through Cd1-to-Cd1' stretch (8.45 Å) (Figure c, ). Then the chiral channels (I) encircled by RR-Cd5(HL)2 supersubunits is equivalent to the left-handed (M) helical channel, while the chiral channels (II) encircled by SS-Cd5(HL)2 supersubunits is equivalent to the right-handed (P) helical channel.

elements.content: One crystallographically independent water molecule (O10) resides in above intertube hydrophilic channel with a diameter of ca. 5.5 Å (nuclear-to-nuclear H···H separation, Figure ). Through hydrogen bonds (O10···O10 2.682 Å or 2.852 Å) (Figure a), two types of infinite water-chains are organized: one is left-handed (M), and another is right-handed (P). Unexpectedly, each helical water-chain possesses three pseudo screw axes, which is different from the reported helices or meso-helices generated from a circle or a lemniscate. The special water-chains in 1 can be regarded as the generation from three circles. In accordance with quasi-periodic structures the water chains can also be called “Berna spiral” since they have two pitch parameters (s 1 = 0.19404c and s 2 = 0.1329c, c is the cell parameter of c-axis) and thus infinite translation period along the chains (c direction). The water-chains achieve the translationally identical arrangement after three turns [3(s 1 + s 2) = c] with a total pich parameter of 13.957 Å (Figure a). While if two adjacent water molecules (O···O separations of 2.852 Å) are designed as only one helical unit, the water-chains can be simplified as normal helices with 31 symmetry and the pitch parameter of 4.562 Å (1/3c). Remarkably, the guest M-helical water-chain is enveloped inside the intertube M-helical channel (I) from RR-Cd5(HL)2, while the P-type water-helix is inside the intertube P-helical channel (II) from SS-Cd5(HL)2 (Figure c). Above results evidently reveal novel chirality transformation and transfer, and molecular recognition, that is, R-Cd3(HL) → RR-Cd5(HL)2 → M-helical channel → M-water-helix, and S-Cd3(HL) → SS-Cd5(HL)2 → P-helical channel → P-water-helix. Because each H2O (O10) molecule is hydrogen-bonded to one N2 atom with the separation of N···O 2.969 Å, it is believed that the chirality transfer and the molecular recognition occur through hydrogen bonds between the host and the guest.
elements.clean_text: One crystallographically independent water molecule (O10) resides in above intertube hydrophilic channel with a diameter of ca. 5.5 Å (nuclear-to-nuclear H⋅⋅⋅H separation, Figure ). Through hydrogen bonds (O10⋅⋅⋅O10 2.682 Å or 2.852 Å) (Figure a), two types of infinite water-chains are organized: one is left-handed (M), and another is right-handed (P). Unexpectedly, each helical water-chain possesses three pseudo screw axes, which is different from the reported helices or meso-helices generated from a circle or a lemniscate. The special water-chains in 1 can be regarded as the generation from three circles. In accordance with quasi-periodic structures the water chains can also be called "Berna spiral" since they have two pitch parameters (s 1 = 0.19404c and s 2 = 0.1329c, c is the cell parameter of c-axis) and thus infinite translation period along the chains (c direction). The water-chains achieve the translationally identical arrangement after three turns [3(s 1 + s 2) = c] with a total pich parameter of 13.957 Å (Figure a). While if two adjacent water molecules (O⋅⋅⋅O separations of 2.852 Å) are designed as only one helical unit, the water-chains can be simplified as normal helices with 31 symmetry and the pitch parameter of 4.562 Å (1/3c). Remarkably, the guest M-helical water-chain is enveloped inside the intertube M-helical channel (I) from RR-Cd5(HL)2, while the P-type water-helix is inside the intertube P-helical channel (II) from SS-Cd5(HL)2 (Figure c). Above results evidently reveal novel chirality transformation and transfer, and molecular recognition, that is, R-Cd3(HL) → RR-Cd5(HL)2 → M-helical channel → M-water-helix, and S-Cd3(HL) → SS-Cd5(HL)2 → P-helical channel → P-water-helix. Because each H2O (O10) molecule is hydrogen-bonded to one N2 atom with the separation of N⋅⋅⋅O 2.969 Å, it is believed that the chirality transfer and the molecular recognition occur through hydrogen bonds between the host and the guest.

elements.content: (a) Space-filling plot of the left-handed (M) and right-handed (P) water-chains [(H2O) n ] hydrogen-bonding with pyridine rings (N2···O10 2.969 Å). Color key: red ball O, white ball H. (b) Top view of stick plot of the M- and P-helical (H2O) n chains with three pseudo screw axes. Terminal vertex: O10 atom.
elements.clean_text: 5  (a) Space-filling plot of the left-handed (M) and right-handed (P) water-chains [(H2O) n ] hydrogen-bonding with pyridine rings (N2⋅⋅⋅O10 2.969 Å). Color key: red ball O, white ball H. (b) Top view of stick plot of the M- and P-helical (H2O) n  chains with three pseudo screw axes. Terminal vertex: O10 atom.

elements.content: As in most synthetic systems, self-organization of metal ions with chiral or achiral spacers resulted in helical motifs. However, a helical chain residing a chiral channel is very limited. In 1 two types of single-stranded water-helices exist inside corresponding chiral channels from two distinct enantiotropic units. Chirality transfer through noncovalent interactions is a significant theme in materials science and biology systems, such as Δ/Λ-[Co(en)3]3+ templates to Δ/Λ inorganic structural motifs through hydrogen bonds, and helix to helix. The new supramolecular system in this work illustrates a unique chirality transformation and transfer from axially asymmetric subunits [RR/SS-Cd5(HL)2] to helical water-chains. The highly ordered water-helix with three pseudo screw axes is an unprecedented example among the existing patterns of water structures, and the pitch of 13.957 Å is the longest among those of reported helical water-chains.
elements.clean_text: As in most synthetic systems, self-organization of metal ions with chiral or achiral spacers resulted in helical motifs. However, a helical chain residing a chiral channel is very limited. In 1 two types of single-stranded water-helices exist inside corresponding chiral channels from two distinct enantiotropic units. Chirality transfer through noncovalent interactions is a significant theme in materials science and biology systems, such as Δ/Λ-[Co(en)3]3+ templates to Δ/Λ inorganic structural motifs through hydrogen bonds, and helix to helix. The new supramolecular system in this work illustrates a unique chirality transformation and transfer from axially asymmetric subunits [RR/SS-Cd5(HL)2] to helical water-chains. The highly ordered water-helix with three pseudo screw axes is an unprecedented example among the existing patterns of water structures, and the pitch of 13.957 Å is the longest among those of reported helical water-chains.

elements.content: Thermal gravimetric analysis of compound 1 shows that a weight loss from room temperature to 146 °C is observed (), corresponding to evacuation of the uncoordinated guest water molecules (calcd.: 3.99%; observed: 3.78%). From 146 to 310 °C, the TGA curve of 1 passes through a flat area, and the host framework starts to be decomposed beyond 310 °C. Notably, the loss of coordinated water molecules is accompanied by the decomposition of the host framework.
elements.clean_text: Thermal gravimetric analysis of compound 1 shows that a weight loss from room temperature to 146 °C is observed (), corresponding to evacuation of the uncoordinated guest water molecules (calcd.: 3.99%; observed: 3.78%). From 146 to 310 °C, the TGA curve of 1 passes through a flat area, and the host framework starts to be decomposed beyond 310 °C. Notably, the loss of coordinated water molecules is accompanied by the decomposition of the host framework.

elements.content: The nitrogen adsorption behavior of 1 has been examined at 77 K (). A known weight (137 mg) of the as-synthesized sample was placed in the quartz tube, which was dried prior to measurement under high vacuum at 150 °C for 6 h to remove the guest molecules. The porosity of 1 is confirmed by its N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm with the typical type-III gas sorption behavior, and a N2 uptake of approximately 16 cm3(STP)·g−1 at P/P 0 = 1.0, which reveals a Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface area of 5.69 m2·g−1.
elements.clean_text: The nitrogen adsorption behavior of 1 has been examined at 77 K (). A known weight (137 mg) of the as-synthesized sample was placed in the quartz tube, which was dried prior to measurement under high vacuum at 150 °C for 6 h to remove the guest molecules. The porosity of 1 is confirmed by its N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm with the typical type-III gas sorption behavior, and a N2 uptake of approximately 16 cm3(STP)⋅g-1 at P/P 0 = 1.0, which reveals a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 5.69 m2⋅g-1.

elements.content: Complex 1 displays a strong blue fluorescent emission band in the solid state at 450 nm upon photoexcitation at 372 nm, while the pure H4L and phen ligands exhibit fluorescent emission bands at 472 nm (upon photoexcitation at 396 nm) and 409 nm (upon photoexcitation at 356 nm), respectively (). The emission peak of 1 is blue-shifted by about 22 nm compared to pure H4L ligand, but the spectrum curve of 1 is similar to that of free H4L. Together with the less coplanar behavior of HL after its coordination to Cd(II) ions, the emission origin of 1 is probably assigned to intraligand charge transfer of HL, as reported for other metal complexes with the pyridine-carboxylate ligands. So this complex may be suitable as an excellent candidate of luminescent materials.
elements.clean_text: Complex 1 displays a strong blue fluorescent emission band in the solid state at 450 nm upon photoexcitation at 372 nm, while the pure H4L and phen ligands exhibit fluorescent emission bands at 472 nm (upon photoexcitation at 396 nm) and 409 nm (upon photoexcitation at 356 nm), respectively (). The emission peak of 1 is blue-shifted by about 22 nm compared to pure H4L ligand, but the spectrum curve of 1 is similar to that of free H4L. Together with the less coplanar behavior of HL after its coordination to Cd(II) ions, the emission origin of 1 is probably assigned to intraligand charge transfer of HL, as reported for other metal complexes with the pyridine-carboxylate ligands. So this complex may be suitable as an excellent candidate of luminescent materials.

elements.content: In summary, a novel luminescent Cd-MOF is designed and synthesized based on the strategy of multifunctional building blocks. The 1-D 63 metal−organic nanotube in 1 appears to be rare among the metal coordination polymers based on rigid carboxylate ligands till now. The chiral channels assembled from asymmetric subunits and occupied by H-bonded helical water-chains with three pseudo screw axes exhibit newfangled cooperative assembly, chirality transformation and transfer, and molecule recognition.
elements.clean_text: In summary, a novel luminescent Cd-MOF is designed and synthesized based on the strategy of multifunctional building blocks. The 1-D 63 metal-organic nanotube in 1 appears to be rare among the metal coordination polymers based on rigid carboxylate ligands till now. The chiral channels assembled from asymmetric subunits and occupied by H-bonded helical water-chains with three pseudo screw axes exhibit newfangled cooperative assembly, chirality transformation and transfer, and molecule recognition.

elements.content:
Figures S1−S12, Tables S1−S3, cif and mol files are available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

References

A mixture of Cd(NO3)2·4H2O (62 mg, 0.2 mmol), phenthnoline (phen) (40 mg, 0.2 mmol), H4L (47 mg, 0.1 mmol), and water (10 mL) was placed in a 23 mL Teflon reactor. After the pH values had been adjusted to 6 by addition of triethylamine (0.04 mL), the mixture was heated at 160 °C for 3 days. Crystals of 1 were obtained on cooling the mixture to room temperature at 10 °C·h−1. Yield: 64 mg (67% based on H4L ligand). Element Anal. Calc. for C84H70.5Cd3N10O22.25: C, 52.68; H, 3.68; N, 7.32. Found: C, 52.80; H, 3.80; N, 7.21%. IR(KBr): ṽ (cm−1) = 3400(m), 3270(m), 3051(w), 1650(m), 1569(vs), 1421(m), 1374(s), 1340(m), 842(m), 781(m), 734(m), 660(m), 593(w). All X-ray crystallographic data were collected on a Bruker SMART CCD 1000 diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 298(2) K. SAINT for data integration, SADABS for absorption correction. The structure was solved by direct methods by use of SHELXS-97 and refined against F2 by full-matrix, least-squares with use of SHELXL-97. Nonhydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and the H1 atoms are found from the different Fourier maps while other hydrogen atoms were placed in geometrically calculated positions with use of a riding model. Crystal data for 1: rhombohedral, space group R3̅c (No. 167) with a = 55.816(3), c = 13.957(2) Å, γ = 120°, V = 37656(6) Å3, Z = 9, d calc =1.519 Mg·m−3, F(000) = 17397, 62227 reflections were collected of which 7308 were unique within 2θmax = 50.02°, 635 parameters, R1 = 0.0788 (I > 2σ(I), 4080 reflections), wR2 = 0.2806 for all data, GOF = 1.006. CCDC-668526 contains the supplementary crystallographic data for this paper.

cln_elements.content:
The 1-D MONTs further produce an interesting 3-D supramolecular aggregate (Figure ). In 1, each MONT is interacted with six equivalent MONTs through the intertube face-to-face π−π interactions of 3.5 Å between phen (N3, N4) blocks (). Because of the existence of obstructive phen entities, the 3-D supramolecular architecture only has a void of 5.4% (2020.6 Å3 out of the unit cell of 37656.0 Å3) as calculated by PLATON.

Thermal gravimetric analysis of compound 1 shows that a weight loss from room temperature to 146 °C is observed (), corresponding to evacuation of the uncoordinated guest water molecules (calcd.: 3.99%; observed: 3.78%). From 146 to 310 °C, the TGA curve of 1 passes through a flat area, and the host framework starts to be decomposed beyond 310 °C. Notably, the loss of coordinated water molecules is accompanied by the decomposition of the host framework.

The nitrogen adsorption behavior of 1 has been examined at 77 K (). A known weight (137 mg) of the as-synthesized sample was placed in the quartz tube, which was dried prior to measurement under high vacuum at 150 °C for 6 h to remove the guest molecules. The porosity of 1 is confirmed by its N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm with the typical type-III gas sorption behavior, and a N2 uptake of approximately 16 cm3(STP)·g−1 at P/P 0 = 1.0, which reveals a Brunauer−Emmett−Teller (BET) surface area of 5.69 m2·g−1.

Because of the existence of obstructive phen entities, the 3-D supramolecular architecture only has a void of 5.4% (2020.6 Å3 out of the unit cell of 37656.0 Å3) as calculated by PLATON.

Notably, the loss of coordinated water molecules is accompanied by the decomposition of the host framework.

The porosity of 1 is confirmed by its N2 adsorption/desorption isotherm with the typical type-III gas sorption behavior, and a N2 uptake of approximately 16 cm3(STP)⋅g-1 at P/P 0 = 1.0, which reveals a Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 5.69 m2⋅g-1.

porosity.condition: out of the unit cell of 37656.0 Å3

decomposition temperature.type: evacuation of the uncoordinated guest water molecules

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of 1. (a) Coordination environments of Cd(II) ions and HL ligands, and the simplified T-type second building unit (SBU). (b) The 1-D metal−organic nanotube (MONT) with 12-membered rings from SBUs by sharing the Cd(II) atoms. The yellow cylinder is artificial. Lavender ball HL, and azure Cd. Other groups are omitted for clarity. (c) The abstracted 1-D 63 topological framework (left), and its top view (right). (d) The near coplanar turbine-like (HL)6 hexamer (denoted as the orange hexagon). The green break-lines represent N1−H1···O3/O4 H-bonds. (e) Top view of the alternative assembly of A and B layers along the c axis direction. A = [Cd2(phen)]3, B = [(HL)Cd1(phen)]6. (f) Side view of the A-B-A′-B′ arrangement in the MONT (A = A′, B = B′, d1 = 3.434 Å, d2 = 6.979 Å).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structure of 1. (a) Coordination environments of Cd(II) ions and HL ligands, and the simplified T-type second building unit (SBU). (b) The 1-D metal-organic nanotube (MONT) with 12-membered rings from SBUs by sharing the Cd(II) atoms. The yellow cylinder is artificial. Lavender ball HL, and azure Cd. Other groups are omitted for clarity. (c) The abstracted 1-D 63 topological framework (left), and its top view (right). (d) The near coplanar turbine-like (HL)6 hexamer (denoted as the orange hexagon). The green break-lines represent N1-H1⋅⋅⋅O3/O4 H-bonds. (e) Top view of the alternative assembly of A and B layers along the c axis direction. A = [Cd2(phen)]3, B = [(HL)Cd1(phen)]6. (f) Side view of the A-B-A'-B' arrangement in the MONT (A = A', B = B', d1 = 3.434 Å, d2 = 6.979 Å).

cln_elements.content: The 3-D supramolecular architecture of metal−organic nanotubes (MONTs) from SBUs and phen ligands. The intertube channels alternately envelop left-handed (M) and right-handed (P) helical water-chains. Methyl groups, other H2O molecules, and H atoms are omitted for clarity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  The 3-D supramolecular architecture of metal-organic nanotubes (MONTs) from SBUs and phen ligands. The intertube channels alternately envelop left-handed (M) and right-handed (P) helical water-chains. Methyl groups, other H2O molecules, and H atoms are omitted for clarity.

(c) Top view of intertube channels containing water-helices encircled by V-type chiral building blocks, and the extended 5-fold helices.

metadata.title:
Spontaneous Assembly of 63 Topological Metal−Organic Nanotubes with Distinct Asymmetric Subunits for the Construction of Hydrophilic Intertube Channels Encapsulating Rare Helical Water-Chains
Communications
